conclusion: The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of an object.
For object A, the displacement at any time t is given by the area under curve A up to that time.
For object B, the displacement at any time t is given by the area under curve B up to that time.
At t = 0, both objects start from rest, so their initial displacements are zero.
As time progresses, the displacement of each object increases as the area under their respective curves accumulates.
The difference in displacement between the two objects at any time t is the difference in the areas under the two curves up to that time.
Let D_A(t) be the displacement of object A at time t.
Let D_B(t) be the displacement of object B at time t.
The difference in displacement is ΔD(t) = D_A(t) - D_B(t).
Curve A is always above curve B for the entire time interval from 0 to t1.
Since D_A(t) > D_B(t) for all t in the interval [0, t1], it follows that ΔD(t) = D_A(t) - D_B(t) > 0 for all t in this interval.
The difference in displacement ΔD(t) is a continuous function because both D_A(t) and D_B(t) are continuous functions.
Since ΔD(t) is positive and continuous, it cannot decrease or become zero within the interval [0, t1].
The difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
